evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in hist_t3_prefinal.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters given the consistent evidence and reports from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal incident.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal event, such as miscommunication and lack of coordination.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t3_prefinal inspection scenario.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics defined for such deficiencies in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t3_prefinal context.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure was present and observable in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal data.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure withstands potential defeaters within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: Mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features identified in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal scope.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal data set.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or exceptions within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 pushback operations in the historical prefinal phase.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in hist_t3_prefinal.

assumptions: Statements from crew members are accurate and complete
No other communication means were used beyond those described
defeaters: If there was evidence of clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If the crew had documented warnings or alerts that were acknowledged and acted upon

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly documents a communication and coordination breakdown among the crew during the incident, as the tug instructor did not receive warnings from the wingman or headset operator (H8), the trainee driver did not speak up when the instructor passed the TRP (H10), and the headset operator assumed the instructor's actions without questioning (H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit transcripts or recordings of communications; reliance on post-incident statements

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure was present and observable in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal data.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control failure in the aircraft during the incident would change my mind.
outcome.reasoning_summary: None of the provided history evidence items (H1-H13) mention or describe any mechanical or control failure being present or observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the pushback or related events.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

defeaters: Evidence showing a marking or environmental deficiency present and observable at the specified time and aircraft.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates the presence or observability of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal data set.

defeaters: If the historical data set did not include explicit documentation of the procedural deviation or if the data set was incomplete or inaccessible.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The historical data set for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 includes detailed descriptions of the pushback event, including the procedural deviation where the aircraft passed the Tug Release Point (TRP) and hit the blast barrier (H4, H7). The presence of multiple eyewitness accounts and procedural details confirms the deviation is documented and available in the historical prefinal data set.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; the evidence directly documents the procedural deviation in the specified data set.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal event, such as miscommunication and lack of coordination.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If the crew had explicit warnings and acknowledged them

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly shows miscommunication and lack of coordination among crew members, as the trainee driver, headset operator, and wingman did not effectively communicate or intervene to prevent the pushback past the TRP, consistent with the claim (H8, H10, H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists about the extent of communication attempts and whether other factors influenced the breakdown

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics defined for such deficiencies in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t3_prefinal context.

assumptions: The TRP described corresponds to the key features and characteristics expected for such deficiencies in the Boeing 737-8AS context
defeaters: Additional evidence showing the TRP markings were non-standard or inconsistent with Boeing 737-8AS requirements
Evidence that the TRP was clearly visible and adequate to prevent the incident

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 defines the TRP location and clearance, H8 and H13 describe the marking and visual signals related to the TRP, indicating the environmental/marking deficiency aligns with key features of TRP markings and their limitations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in the adequacy and visibility of the TRP markings and signals; no explicit Boeing 737-8AS standard for TRP markings provided

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters given the consistent evidence and reports from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal incident.

assumptions: The statements from involved personnel are accurate and complete
No other communication channels or warnings were used beyond those described
defeaters: If evidence showed active communication or warnings were given and ignored
If there were contradictory reports about awareness of the TRP or pushback status

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Consistent reports from the tug instructor, trainee driver, and headset operator indicate no communication or warnings were given to prevent the pushback past the TRP, showing resistance to defeaters (H8, H10, H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statements about communication attempts beyond visual signals; possible unreported verbal communication

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 pushback operations in the historical prefinal phase.

assumptions: The TRP and pushback procedures described are the key features referenced
The described actions and observations reflect typical Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA pushback operations
defeaters: If evidence showed the procedural deviation was due to factors unrelated to the key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA pushback operations
If the TRP or pushback procedures were different than described
If the tug instructor's actions were standard and not a deviation

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly describes the pushback procedure and the deviation from the TRP, including the tug instructor's actions and the small size of the TRP (H4, H7, H8, H12, H13), supporting alignment with key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA pushback operations in the historical prefinal phase.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the deviation was intentional or due to procedural misunderstanding

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features identified in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal scope.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction during the event
Reports or data indicating failure in aircraft or tug controls
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history indicates any mechanical or control failure; all information relates to human actions and procedural aspects during pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t3_prefinal inspection scenario.

assumptions: The TRP marking size and visibility directly impact the robustness of identification.
Human factors such as attention and communication effectiveness influence the resistance to defeaters.
defeaters: If additional evidence showed clearer or more prominent TRP markings or more effective communication methods were in place, the robustness would increase.
If evidence indicated that the visual signals were adequate and consistently used, the resistance to defeaters would be stronger.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence indicates the TRP marking was small and the visual stop signal was insufficient (H8, H13), and the clearance at the TRP was limited (H7), suggesting the identification of the environmental or marking deficiency is somewhat robust but vulnerable to human factors and limited visibility, thus only partially resistant to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the sufficiency and visibility of TRP markings and communication signals

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew duty logs, communication device records, and witness statements to confirm crew presence and availability

children_spec.statement: Communication equipment was operational and accessible to the crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect maintenance records and equipment status reports to verify functionality and accessibility of communication devices

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not incapacitated or otherwise unable to communicate
children_spec.test_procedure: Review medical records, incident reports, and crew statements to determine if any crew member was incapacitated

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are present and visible in the operational area
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the operational area for presence and visibility of all required environmental markings

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are maintained in a condition that ensures their availability during operations
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess the condition of environmental markings for wear, damage, or obstruction that would reduce availability

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are not obscured or removed during the relevant operational timeframe
children_spec.test_procedure: Review operational records and conduct physical inspections to verify markings remain unobscured and present

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or exceptions within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal context.

assumptions: The statements from involved personnel are accurate and complete
No other unreported counterarguments or exceptions existed at the time
defeaters: If evidence showed that the tug instructor ignored clear warnings or standard procedures deliberately
If the headset operator or wingman had actively tried to intervene or signal the deviation
If the procedural deviation was found to be a known and accepted exception in training or operations

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows that the procedural deviation was not challenged or countered by involved personnel during the event, indicating it withstood scrutiny against potential counterarguments or exceptions in the historical context.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether all involved parties fully understood or recognized the deviation as problematic

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure withstands potential defeaters within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal context.

assumptions: Mechanical/control failure would be evident if present in the incident narrative or observations, but no such evidence is given.
defeaters: Direct mechanical inspection reports showing no failure
Evidence of mechanical malfunction causing uncontrolled movement
Testimony or data indicating mechanical controls functioned normally

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows human factors and communication issues contributed to the incident, with no direct indication that mechanical or control failure was resisted or withstood defeaters; the tug instructor's control and decisions were central (H8, H10, H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical system diagnostic evidence or failure analysis provided; ambiguity whether mechanical failure occurred or was a factor.

node.statement: Communication equipment was operational and accessible to the crew

defeaters: Evidence showing explicit communication failures due to equipment malfunction or inaccessibility
Statements confirming crew could not access or operate communication equipment

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: While communication equipment was present and used (H1), the lack of warnings about the impending collision (H8) and assumptions made by crew members (H12) indicate that communication was operational but not effectively accessible or utilized by the crew.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence about the operational status or accessibility of communication equipment beyond usage mentions; ambiguity about whether equipment was fully functional and accessible to all crew members.

node.statement: Environmental markings are not obscured or removed during the relevant operational timeframe

defeaters: Direct evidence that markings were obscured or removed during the timeframe
Statements from personnel noting obscured or missing markings

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence indicates the TRP ground markings existed and were known to personnel (H7, H13), but no direct statement confirms markings were obscured or removed during the operational timeframe. The small size of the TRP (H13) may affect visibility but does not prove obscuration or removal.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence about the condition or visibility of environmental markings during the relevant timeframe

children_spec.statement: Mechanical components required for control were physically present and intact
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect maintenance records and physical inspection reports to confirm presence and integrity of mechanical control components

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components were accessible and not obstructed during operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Review cockpit and control system layout and any obstruction reports or damage assessments

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components were free from failures such as breaks, jams, or disconnections
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze failure logs, maintenance records, and post-incident inspections for evidence of mechanical faults

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control system was properly connected and integrated with other control systems
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine system integration tests and wiring or linkage inspections to verify proper connections

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the incident

assumptions: Being seated beside each other or walking near the tug implies physical presence and reachability during the incident
defeaters: If evidence showed any crew member was absent or unreachable during the incident
If communication devices were non-functional or crew were incapacitated

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Multiple history items (H1, H3, H8, H11, H12, H13) confirm that crew members (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) were physically present and reachable during the incident, with detailed descriptions of their positions and interactions.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statements about physical reachability distance or any crew member being unreachable; assumptions made based on described proximity and interactions.

node.statement: Crew members were not incapacitated or otherwise unable to communicate

assumptions: Qualified crew members were capable of communication
No hidden incapacitation occurred as it would likely be documented
defeaters: Evidence of any crew member being incapacitated or unable to communicate
Reports of communication equipment failure or crew medical issues

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman.
The wingman was also a qualified headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Multiple evidence items (H1, H8, H9, H10, H11, H12, H13) indicate that all crew members involved were qualified, aware of procedures, and actively communicating or observing, with no indication of incapacitation or inability to communicate.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statements about crew incapacitation; assumption based on absence of contrary evidence

children_spec.statement: The pushback procedure deviated from the standard checklist steps
children_spec.test_procedure: Review the recorded checklist steps during pushback and compare them to the standard procedure to identify any omissions or alterations

children_spec.statement: The timing and sequencing of pushback actions did not conform to prescribed protocols
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze the timing logs and sequence of pushback maneuvers against the procedural timeline to detect discrepancies

children_spec.statement: Communication between the flight crew and ground personnel during pushback was inconsistent with standard procedures
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine audio recordings and transcripts of communications during pushback for deviations from required phraseology and timing

node.statement: Environmental markings are maintained in a condition that ensures their availability during operations

assumptions: TRP ground markings are considered part of environmental markings
Availability includes visibility and effectiveness of markings during operations
defeaters: If evidence showed the markings were clearly visible and in good condition
If there were documented procedures ensuring effective use of markings and signals
If the collision was caused by factors unrelated to marking availability

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence indicates the TRP marking was present but small and possibly insufficiently conspicuous (H7, H13). The tug instructor noted the visual stop signal was inadequate and no warnings were given before the collision (H8), suggesting markings and signals were not effectively maintained or used to ensure availability during operations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on the physical condition or maintenance status of the environmental markings; ambiguity about whether markings were adequate or properly used.

node.statement: Communication between the flight crew and ground personnel during pushback was inconsistent with standard procedures

assumptions: Standard procedures require active and consistent communication between flight crew and ground personnel during pushback.
The lack of warnings or intervention constitutes inconsistency with standard procedures.
defeaters: If evidence showed active, clear, and timely communication warnings were given and ignored, or if standard procedures allowed such passive communication.
If the headset operator or wingman had communicated effectively but the tug instructor disregarded it.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows that communication between the flight crew and ground personnel (headset operator, wingman, tug drivers) was limited and passive, with no warnings given despite the pushback continuing past the TRP (H1, H8, H10, H12). This indicates inconsistency with standard procedures requiring active communication and intervention to prevent such deviations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity about exact standard communication procedures and whether the passive communication observed meets or deviates from those standards.

node.statement: The pushback procedure deviated from the standard checklist steps

assumptions: The TRP is the standard stopping point per checklist
Stopping at the TRP is required to avoid collision with the blast barrier
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not a mandatory stopping point or that continuing past it was standard procedure
If the tug instructor had communicated a justified reason for continuing past the TRP

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The aircraft moved beyond the designated Tug Release Point (H4), indicating deviation from standard pushback stopping procedures. The tug instructor acknowledged limitations in the stop signal method (H8), and both the trainee and headset operator observed the pushback continuing past the TRP without intervention (H10, H12), supporting procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity about whether continuing past the TRP was ever acceptable or part of the checklist

defeaters: If evidence showed the pushback timing and sequencing matched prescribed protocols or that the TRP was not a strict stop point in procedures.

The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
